LATIN 1.title: Elementary Latin
LATIN 1.description: The beginning course in classical Latin, and first in a three-  quarter sequence introducing fundamentals of grammar, syntax, and reading skills. Concepts taught using written exercises. Interesting aspects of Ancient Roman society are introduced.

LATIN 2.title: Elementary Latin
LATIN 2.prereq_description: Latin 1 with a grade of C or better.
LATIN 2.description: A continuation of Latin 1. Emphasis on mastering grammar and building vocabulary.

LATIN 3.title: Intermediate Latin
LATIN 3.prereq_description: Latin 2 with a grade of C or better.
LATIN 3.description: Continuation of Latin 2. Emphasis on building a working vocabulary and the syntax of complex sentences. Reading in classical prose introduce students to ancient Roman literature and culture.

LATIN 100.title: Introduction To Latin Prose
LATIN 100.prereq_description: Latin 3 with a grade of C or better.
LATIN 100.description: Reading and analysis of various Latin prose authors to develop reading skills and introduce study of the style and thought of historical, rhetorical and/or philosophical writers.

LATIN 101.title: Introduction To Latin Poetry
LATIN 101.prereq_description: Latin 100 with a grade of C or better.
LATIN 101.description: Readings in various authors (often including Catallus and Ovid) to develop reading skills, introduce an understanding of meter, and begin study of the style and thought of Latin poetry.

LATIN 102.title: Readings In Latin Literature
LATIN 102.description: Selected readings in Latin prose and/or poetry are designed to develop reading proficiency, and to help students make the transition to more advanced study of classical Latin literature.

LATIN 103.title: Medieval Latin Readings
LATIN 103.description: Graded and selected reading and study of medieval Latin prose and verse writers.

LATIN 111.title: Roman Epic
LATIN 111.description: Reading, translation, and discussion of authors such as Virgil and Lucan.

LATIN 112.title: Roman Elegy
LATIN 112.description: Translation and discussion of the elegiac works of Tibullus, Propertius, and/or Ovid. Consideration of the genre of elegy in its literary and historical contexts, with special attention to elegiac themes and motifs.

LATIN 114.title: Roman Comedy
LATIN 114.description: Plautus and Terence. Reading of complete plays and study of the origins of Roman comedy.

LATIN 115.title: The Roman Novel
LATIN 115.description: Reading and study of passages from Petronius and Apuleius with attention to the language and style of their satiric novels and to their social and historical context.

LATIN 116.title: Cicero: Essays, Letters, And Orations
LATIN 116.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
LATIN 116.description: Reading and study of selected works of Cicero, normally one of the major speeches. Translation; discussion of philological, stylistic, and rhetorical points.

LATIN 120.title: Sallust
LATIN 120.description: Study of one of the extant works of Rome's first great historian: the Bellum Catilinae or the Bellum Iugurthinum. Translation; discussion of philological, stylistic, literary, and historical points.

LATIN 122.title: Livy
LATIN 122.description: Reading and study of the annalistic history of Livy with attention to the author's style, literary, and historical context, and the recent scholarly approaches to the text.

LATIN 123.title: Tacitus
LATIN 123.description: Study of portions of one of Tacitus' major histories of the early empire (Annales, Historiae), or of the shorter works (Agricola, Dialogus, Germania). Translation; discussion of philological, stylistic, literary, and historical points.

LATIN 124.title: Caesar
LATIN 124.description: Study of Caesar as historian and Latin prose stylist. Extensive reading.

LATIN 125.title: Roman Biography
LATIN 125.description: Exploration of Roman biographical writing: its historical and literary context, themes, and techniques. Translation and discussion of selections from the biographies of Nepos, Suetonius, and Tacitus, as well as biographical passages from the histories of Sallust, Livy, and Tacitus.

LATIN 134.title: Lucretius
LATIN 134.description: Reading, translation, and discussion of style, meter and philosophy in Lucretius' epic poem De Rerum Natura.

LATIN 135.title: Vergil
LATIN 135.description: Reading, translation, and discussion of Vergil's epic poem Aeneid, as well as his Georgics and Eclogues.

LATIN 136.title: Ovid
LATIN 136.description: Translation and discussion of Ovid's epic or elegiac poetry (Metamorphoses, Fasti, Ars Amatoria, Tristia, Heroides) in its literary, social and historical contexts.

LATIN 137.title: Catullus
LATIN 137.description: Translation and discussion of Catullus' poetry in its literary, social, and historical contexts.

LATIN 138.title: Horace
LATIN 138.description: Reading, translation, and discussion of selected poems of Horace (Odes, Epodes, Satires, Epistles) in their literary, social, and historical contexts.

LATIN 139.title: Seneca: Tragedies
LATIN 139.description: Reading, translation, and discussion of several tragedies by Seneca.

LATIN 199.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and department chair. upper-division standing; completion of 2 upper-division courses in Latin.
LATIN 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 4.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
LATIN 199.description: Independent investigations in Latin language and literature.

LATIN 210.title: Latin Prose Composition
LATIN 210.description: Study of Latin grammar and syntax through English composition, combined with analysis of Latin prose style in a variety of authors, including Cato, Caesar, Cicero, Sallust, and Tacitus.

LATIN 211.title: Roman Epic
LATIN 211.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LATIN 211.description: Advanced reading, translation, and discussion of authors such as Vergil and Lucan.

LATIN 212.title: Roman Elegy
LATIN 212.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
LATIN 212.description: Advanced study and discussion of the elegiac works of Tibullus, Propertius, and/or Ovid. Consideration of the genre of elegy in its literary and historical contexts, with special attention to elegiac themes and motifs.

LATIN 213.title: Roman Satire
LATIN 213.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LATIN 213.description: Advanced readings in Horace, Juvenal, Persius, and/or Martial.

LATIN 214.title: Roman Comedy
LATIN 214.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LATIN 214.description: Advanced study of Plautus and Terence. Reading of complete plays and study of the origins of Roman comedy.

LATIN 215.title: The Roman Novel
LATIN 215.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LATIN 215.description: Advanced study of Petronius and/or Apuleius, with attention to the language and style of their satiric novels, and to their social and historical context.

LATIN 216.title: Cicero: Essays, Letters, and Orations
LATIN 216.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
LATIN 216.description: Advanced reading and study of selected works of Cicero, normally one of the major speeches. Translation; discussion of philological, stylistic, and rhetorical points; introduction to current scholarship.

LATIN 218.title: Roman Epistles
LATIN 218.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LATIN 218.description: Advanced reading, translation, and discussion of authors such as Cicero, Seneca, and Pliny.

LATIN 220.title: Sallust
LATIN 220.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
LATIN 220.description: Advanced study of one of the extant works of Rome's first great historian: The Bellum Catilinae or the Bellum Iugurthinum. Translations; discussion of philological, stylistic, literary, and historical points; introduction to current scholarship.

LATIN 222.title: Livy
LATIN 222.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LATIN 222.description: Advanced reading and study of the annalistic history of Livy with attention to the author's style, literary and historical context, and recent scholarly approaches to the text.

LATIN 223.title: Tacitus
LATIN 223.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
LATIN 223.description: Advanced study of portions of one of Tacitus' major histories of the early Empire (Annales, Historiae), or of the shorter works (Agricola, Dialogus, Germania). Translation; discussion of philological, stylistic, literary, and historical points; introduction to current scholarship.

LATIN 224.title: Caesar
LATIN 224.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LATIN 224.description: Advanced study of Caesar as historian and as Latin prose stylist.

LATIN 225.title: Roman Biography
LATIN 225.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.

LATIN 234.title: Lucretius
LATIN 234.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
LATIN 234.description: Intensive study in the poetry and Epicurean philosophy of Lucretius.

LATIN 235.title: Vergil
LATIN 235.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LATIN 235.description: Advanced reading, translation, and discussion of Vergil's epic poem Aeneid, as well as his Georgics and Eclogues.

LATIN 236.title: Ovid
LATIN 236.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units.
LATIN 236.description: Advanced study of Ovid's epic or elegiac poetry (Metamorphoses, Fasti, Ars Amatoria, Tristia, Heroides) in its literary, social, and historical contexts.

LATIN 237.title: Catullus
LATIN 237.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
LATIN 237.description: Advanced study of Catullus' poetry in its literary, social, and historical contexts.

LATIN 238.title: Horace
LATIN 238.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
LATIN 238.description: Advanced study of selected poems of Horace (Odes, Epodes, Satire Epistles) in their literary, social, and historical contexts, with an introduction to current scholarship.

LATIN 239.title: Seneca: Tragedies
LATIN 239.description: Reading, translation, and discussion of several tragedies by Seneca.

LATIN 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
LATIN 596.prereq_description: Written proposal approved by department chair and graduate advisor.

LATIN 598.title: Master's Thesis Research and Preparation
LATIN 598.prereq_description: Graduate standing and consent of instructor and graduate advisor.
LATIN 598.comments: No unit credit allowed toward degree.
